utterances: On the other hand, Tsarnaev's attorneys themselves have argued they can't afford to wait for sentencing to first introduce the idea of Tsarnaev as a vulnerable kid caught in the sway of his wicked older brother.
Longtime defense attorney Jack Cunha says Tsarnaev's lawyers have to lay the foundation now.
It would be foolish to wait.
People are forming impressions, conclusions as the evidence comes in.
So you have to be presenting your point of view right from the get-go.

But that means following what may be the government's most emotional evidence of all, medical examiners' excruciating details of how the bodies of a 23-year-old student and an 8-year-old boy were brutally blown apart by Tsarnaev's bomb.
Boston University law professor Karen Pita Loor says the challenge for defense is to try and make its case as jurors may still be wiping away tears.
It is very difficult to now bring them down to a place where they are not so passionately overwrought with anguish so that they can actually listen.

After a conviction, defense attorneys would have a lot more leeway to cast Tsarnaev as a troubled teen drawn in to his brother's plot, though prosecutors would also keep making their case of a man hiding from everyone what they call the murder in his heart.
Tovia Smith, NPR News, Boston.
In Amsterdam, a new Rembrandt unveiled yesterday has the tech world buzzing.
That's right, the tech world, not the art world so much.
That's because the new Rembrandt is not an actual Rembrandt, but a 3-D printer creation.
Of course, the man, Rembrandt van Rijn, has been dead for almost 450 years.
The ad firm J.
Walter Thompson Amsterdam used a computer program to analyze 346 official works by the artist.
Bas Korsten is the director of the project.
A computer learned how to re-create a new Rembrandt right eye, and we did that for all facial features.
And after that, we assembled those facial features using the geometrical dimensions that Rembrandt used to use in his own work.
The program came up with a portrait of a middle-aged bearded man, just like one of the portraits that made Rembrandt famous.
And it looks like an actual Rembrandt, right down to the texture of the brushstrokes, which the 3-D printer re-created.
But Korsten will be the first to tell you it's not legit.
I wish it was that good, and it isn't.
I think the expert eye sees that this isn't a real Rembrandt.
And that's also got to do with the state of technology that we're in, the amount of time that we had.
I mean, every extra month would have been a better painting.
Even a better painting will never be the same as one by the actual artist.
But Korsten says the program, which started as just a PR stunt for a client, could be a boon for the art of restoring lost masterpieces.
Yeah.
So it amazes me that - I can't even imagine to buy a house anytime in the future.
And I'm a good consumer.
I have savings in the bank.
I have a steady job at this point.
I don't have any debt.

But I don't see myself, with this current economy - and even after this bubble, you know, the bubble already burst - but even once we've reached rock bottom, I don't see how I could possibly try to even want to get a home, as opposed to my parents who did it nearly 20 years ago.
And they've, you know, they've almost paid off the house.
They didn't have to refinance any sort of mortgage trick.
You're right.

Again, quoting this story, this op-ed piece in the Los Angeles Times, my parents' generation of Mexicans came to this country with nothing - many of them illegally - and they still live as if they were back on the rancho.
Yet all of my uncles, aunts and their middle-aged Mexican immigrant friends own their homes.
The point you just made.
And you couldn't afford a down payment at this point despite your master's degree.

I could afford a down payment, but then I would be staring at hundreds of thousands of dollars in debt for the next 30 years, especially - it might be a little bit different since I'm here in Southern California, where the housing market has always been more inflated than the rest of the country.
I'm sure if I went to Iowa or Nebraska, where you have dying towns, maybe I might I want to live there.
But nothing against the good folks in Nebraska, I really like living in Southern California.
So as it is, I'll just be content with my one-bedroom apartment in a kind of sketchy neighborhood in Santa Ana, California.
You also write that in some ways your parent's generation is better situated right now, more nimble than their offspring.
Again, I have a master's degree in Latin American studies, that allows me to maybe once in a while guest lecture at a junior college and write articles for newspapers or blogs at this point.
My dad, on the other hand, he had a fourth grade education.
He came to this country in a trunk of Chevy.
He's now a citizen through the Amnesty Act.
But if anybody needs a carpenter, a plumber, an electrician, a swimming pool cleaner, a truck driver, both short haul and big rig, then you could contact Lorenzo Arellano.
He's much more able to find a job, I think, at this point, than I would to be able to with my advanced degree.
And that turns this whole idea on its head.
It really does.
And it's the same situation with all my cousins.
And we used to joke, a couple of years ago, if anything ever bad happens to the United States, then we could go back to our parents' ancestral village in Mexico, in central Mexico.
Of course, now, with the drug war just booming beyond control into tragedy, we can't - we don't have that option anymore.
So instead we just get to share bunk beds with our little brothers until we're 28 or 29 or until we get married.
And that bunk bed, you wrote at the end of your piece, I think, I hope, with your tongue and cheek, starting to look pretty good right now.
No, my brother's now 18 years old.
There's no way in heck that he'd be able to accept me back in a bunk bed.
So just on that alone it's not going to happen.
We're talking with Gustavo Arellano, the author of ""Orange County: A Personal History,"" about a piece he wrote about his family and the American dream.
His parents arrived here, as he said, with nothing.
His father had a fourth grade education.
He has a master's degree.
And he believes his father is better situated right now in this economy than he might be.
Is this your story?
What about the American dream and this recession?
Give us a call, 800-989-8255, email us, talk@npr.org.
Abubakar(ph) joins us on the line from Charlottesville in Virginia.
Hello.
How are you, Neal?
Thank you very much for accepting my call.
Go ahead, please.
Well, I came to this country 15 years ago.
That was the time when Bill Clinton was the president of this country.
The economy was good, everything was fine, I was enjoying it.
I mean, I am an African.
I came from Sierra Leone.
I've been here, but I'm beginning to think about it seriously whether is this something I really want to do or not, you know?
I mean, I have my children here.
They were born here to an American lady, which is very wonderful.
And I am in school.
I'm (unintelligible) my RN degree right now.

I'm seriously thinking that if I finish, probably the best thing for me to do if the economic continue the way it is, I would love to go back and work for non-governmental organization or something and help people out in Africa or some other part of the world.
And that would've been - I don't mean to put this too harshly, but pretty hard to think about, well, certainly Sierra Leone, given the civil war situation there just a couple of years ago.
Exactly.
It is very hard in Sierra Leone, too, at the same time.
But I do believe with my background and a graduate from United States of America, I do believe that probably it'd make a lot of difference.
Because I tell you what, the difference between Africa and here is here big collectors go after you.
You are supposed to certain things under your name and everything else.
I don't think that the bill will be as, you know, large as it is here.
And I will worry less, to be honest with you.
Abubakar, we wish you and your family the best of luck.
Thank you.
And Gustavo Arellano, as you hear that story, well, I think he's thinking some of the same things that you were.
Definitely.
And that's something in the immigrant experience that has always happened where people, if they just didn't like the situation in the United States, they just went back.

I once read a statistic that half of the immigrants who came from Italy the turn of the 20th century, half of them returned back, either they got their money and then went back or they just didn't like the situation here.

Meanwhile, the people who might - don't have as many roots here or haven't had so much invested here, like myself, we might be thinking of moving on to other places, maybe even to Canada or, you know, some place where it might be a little bit easier to live.

Some place where it might be easier to live, yet, this country has thrived so much on the labor and the dreams of immigrants, you talked about the Italians, the Irish, everybody else, including now the Mexicans.
Exactly.
And of course, myself, as a child of immigrants, I am another part of the American story.
I'm the child - I'm the spoiled child of immigrants who really doesn't know how good he has it, as opposed to my parents who know true poverty.
I never grew up in true poverty like my parents.
I never grew up living next, you know, living in a dirt ranch out over in Mexico.
I grew up here in the United States.

Therefore, because I didn't grow up without poverty, I might be a little bit more whiny or more needy than, say, the - my parents' immigrant generation, who openly laughs, by the way, at the travails of their children, saying, oh, you know, you kids with your advanced degrees and your white-collar jobs whining about how you can't buy a house.
You got to pull up your bootstraps as, you know, as the great American cliché says, and go out and get them.
Let's talk with Jerry(ph).
Jerry calling us from San Bruno, California.
How you doing?
I'm good, Jerry.
How are you?
Good, good.
Thanks for having me on the show here.
You know, I have two children, 20 and 3.
And I'm concerned that they all - they'll miss the American dream.
Twenty and…
Given the current environment.
Twenty years old and three years old?
Yes.
